title: Magnetic susceptibility of the QCD vacuum

title_detail.value: Magnetic susceptibility of the QCD vacuum

summary:
We investigate the magnetic susceptibility of the QCD vacuum, based on the
instanton vacuum. Starting from the instanton liquid model for the instanton
vacuum, we derive the light-quark partition function $Z[V,T,\hat{m}]$ in the
presence of the current quark mass $\hat{m}$ as well as the external Abelian
vector and tensor fields. We calculate a two-point correlation function
relevant for the magnetic susceptibility and derive it beyond the chiral limit.
We obtain for the different flavors the following magnetic susceptibility:
$\chi_{u,d}< i\psi_{u,d}^\dagger \psi_{u,d}>_0 \sim 40\sim45 {\rm MeV}$, while
$\chi_{s}< i\psi_s^\dagger \psi_s >_0 \simeq 6\sim 10 {\rm MeV}$ with the quark
condensate $<i\psi^\dagger \psi>_0$.

Abstract
We investigate the magnetic susceptibility of the QCD vacuum, based on the instanton vacuum.
Starting from the instanton liquid model for the instanton vacuum, we derive the light-quark
partition function Z[V, T, m̂] in the presence of the current quark mass m̂ as well as the external
Abelian vector and tensor fields. We calculate a two-point correlation function relevant for the
magnetic susceptibility and derive it beyond the chiral limit. We obtain for the different flavors the

ψu,d i0 ∼ 40 ∼ 45 MeV, while χs hiψs† ψs i0 ≃ 6 ∼ 10 MeV
with the quark condensate hiψ † ψi0 .

 1. The QCD vacuum is one of the most complicated states filled not only by perturbative
but also strong nonperturbative fluctuations. In particular, the condensates of the quarks
and gluons characterize its nonperturbative aspect. The quark condensate plays a role of
an order parameter associated with spontaneous chiral symmetry breaking (SχSB) which is
probably one of the most important quantities for low-energy hadronic phenomena.
The presence of a constant external electromagnetic field Fμν induces another type of
condensates leading to the nonzero magnetic susceptibility χf of the QCD vacuum defined
as:
h0|ψf† σμν ψf |0iF = ef χf hiψf† ψf i0 Fμν ,

(1)

where ef denotes the quark electric charge, f is the corresponding flavor. It is natural
to have the quark condensate hiψf† ψf i0 in the chiral limit as a normalization factor in the
right-hand side of Eq. (1), since SχSB is responsible for these quantities, i.e. the quark
condensate and magnetic susceptibility. In a recent paper [1] it was suggested that the
magnetic susceptibility χf may be measured in the exclusive photoproduction of hard dijets
γ + N → (q̄q) + N. The value of χf was predicted by using the method of the QCD sum
rule and vector dominance [2, 3, 4]: χf hiψf† ψf i0 = 40 ∼ 70 MeV at the scale of 1 GeV.
In the present work, we want to investigate the magnetic susceptibility χf of the QCD
vacuum within the framework of the instanton vacuum. Since the instanton vacuum explains
SχSB naturally via quark zero modes, it may provide a good framework to study the χf .
Moreover, there are only two parameters in this approach, namely the average instanton size
ρ ≈ 31 fm and average inter-instanton distance R ≈ 1 fm. The normalization scale of this
approach can be defined by the average size of instantons and is approximately equal to ρ−1 ≈
0.6 GeV. The values of the ρ and R were estimated many years ago phenomenologically by
Ref. [5] as well as theoretically by Ref. [6]. Furthermore, it was recently confirmed in various
lattice simulations of the QCD vacuum [7, 8, 9]. Very recent lattice calculations of the quark
propagator [10, 11] are in a remarkable agreement with that of Ref. [6].
The magnetic susceptibility of the QCD vacuum was estimated already in Ref. [20],
however, done in the chiral limit and without the consideration of the current conservation.
Since we want to investigate it beyond the chiral limit, we first need to extend Refs. [12,
13, 14] and Lee-Bardeen formula [15] for a low-frequency (p ≪ ρ−1 ) part of the quark
determinant:
Detlow = det B, Bij = im̂δij + aji , a−+ = −hΦ−,0 |i/∂ |Φ+,0 i,

(2)

taking into account the current quark mass. Here, m̂ denotes a current quark mass, which is
assumed to be small, aij stands for the overlapping matrix element of the quark zero modes
Φ±,0 generated by instantons (antiinstantons). In general, we define Φ±,n by the following
equation:
(i/∂ + /A± )Φ±,n = λn Φ±,n ,

(3)

where Aμ,± is an instanton (antiinstanton) field and λ0 = 0 by convention. The matrix
element aij is nonzero only between instantons and antiinstantons and vice versa due to
specific chiral properties of the zero modes.
The overlapping of the quark zero modes allows quarks to propagate through the
instanton-antiinstanton medium by jumping from one instanton to another one. Hence,
Detlow is reduced to the determinant of the finite matrix B in the subspace of zero modes.
2

fermionic determinant is proportional to m|N+ −N− | and strongly suppresses the fluctuations
of |N+ − N− |. Therefore, we can take N+ = N− = N/2 in the final formulas.
In order to calculate the magnetic susceptibility, we have to find the light-quark partition

tensor Tμν fields. So, we first calculate a zero-mode approximated quark propagator S̃ in
the instanton ensemble and in the presence of these external fields. Using this propagator,

that the low-energy theorem of the axial anomaly related to the process GG̃ → γγ (see also
[18, 19]) is satisfied.
In the present work we refine the derivation of the gauged effective chiral action and
apply it to the calculations of the magnetic susceptibility χf of the QCD vacuum, taking
into account both current quark mass and nonlocal currents.

It is obvious that Ṽ±,f [ψ † , ψ] indicates the nonlocal interaction between constituent quarks
generated by instantons. Since the range of the integration in Eq.(28) is truncated at ρ,
which is defined by zero-mode functions Φ±,0 , the range of the nonlocality is determined by
ρ.
Note that the external vector field Vμ gauges not only the kinetic term of the effective
action but also its interaction one Ṽ±,f [ψf† , ψf ] in Eq. (28). The reason is clear: Since the
instanton-induced interaction is nonlocal, the gauge connection Lf must be attached to
each fermionic line so that the effective action may be gauge-invariant. Unfortunately, we
encounter an ambiguity arising from this gauge connection, since it is path-dependent in
general. However, we will show now that the most preferable path can be found in the
present case.

5. Figure 1 shows the magnetic susceptibility χf hiψf† ψf i0 as a function of the current
quark mass, with the zero-mode form factor in Eq. (44) employed. It is a monotonically
decreasing function as mf increases, since the third term with mf ln mf in Eq. (55) suppresses
the first and second ones noticeably as mf gets larger. In fact, its value is around −4.0 MeV
for up and down quark masses mu,d ≃ 5 MeV, whereas for the strange quark mass ms ≃ 200
MeV it turns out to be −49 MeV. Thus, it almost cancels the leading term in the case of
the strange magnetic susceptibility χs . Moreover, the nonlocal part is responsible for about
40% of the total magnetic susceptibility in the chiral limit and diminishes linearly but slowly
as mf increases. It implies that it is essential to treat the vector current properly in the
presence of the nonlocal interaction, in particular, in the case of the magnetic susceptibility.
As a result, the magnetic susceptibility for the up and down quarks is: χu,d = 40 ∼ 45 MeV,
whereas for the strange quark we obtain χs = 6 ∼ 10 MeV. As for the up and down quarks,
the present result is comparable to that of Ref. [2, 3, 4].

A comparison between different types of the form factors is depicted in Fig. 2. As already

the dependence of the magnetic susceptibility on a type of the form factors is not sensitive.
6. In the present work, we have investigated the magnetic susceptibility of the QCD
vacuum within the framework of the nonlocal chiral quark model from the instanton vacuum.
We first have constructed the effective partition function in the presence of the external
vector and tensor fields as well as the current quark mass. It was shown that for the constant
electromagnetic field strength the present result is independent of the path which is selected
for the gauge connection. We found that the result is a smoothly decreasing function of mf :
